articles.headline: Uber Board Stands by Travis Kalanick as It Reveals Plans to Repair Its Image
articles.snippet: In a conference call with executives, Uber presented a list of changes it plans to make to improve morale and repair its tarnished reputation.
articles.abstract: In a conference call with executives, Uber presented a list of changes it plans to make to improve morale and repair its tarnished reputation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The board of Uber is confident in its chief executive, Travis Kalanick, board member Arianna Huffington said on Tuesday, providing a show of support as the embattled ride-hailing company seeks to repair its reputation.

articles.headline: Gorsuch Says He’d Rule Against Trump if Law Required It
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court nominee also repeated his earlier private criticism of the president’s attacks on judges who rule against him.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court nominee also repeated his earlier private criticism of the president’s attacks on judges who rule against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, sought to assure the Senate and the nation on Tuesday that he would be a fair-minded and independent justice. He said he would not hesitate to rule against Mr. Trump if the law required it, and he repeated his earlier private criticism of Mr. Trump’s attacks on judges who had ruled against the administration.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Market Dip Bucks a Streak of Trump-Inspired Optimism
articles.snippet: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index had gone 64 consecutive trading days without declining more than 1 percent in a trading session.
articles.abstract: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index had gone 64 consecutive trading days without declining more than 1 percent in a trading session.
articles.lead_paragraph: It had been one of Wall Street’s more confounding streaks.

articles.headline: India’s ‘Phone Romeos’ Look for Ms. Right via Wrong Numbers
articles.snippet: As mobile phone use grows, more young men are calling women at random, hoping to strike up a relationship, but sometimes harassing them.
articles.abstract: As mobile phone use grows, more young men are calling women at random, hoping to strike up a relationship, but sometimes harassing them.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUCKNOW, India — In a glass-sided call center, police constables clicketyclack on computer keyboards, on the trail of a particularly Indian sort of criminal.

articles.headline: Trump Says Regulations Impede. Perhaps Not in the Electric Car Business.
articles.snippet: Sometimes the only way to push technology advances is through rules. Loosening the ones on fuel economy could leave the car industry out of step with the future.
articles.abstract: Sometimes the only way to push technology advances is through rules. Loosening the ones on fuel economy could leave the car industry out of step with the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump is not fond of regulations. Within weeks of taking office, he and his appointees began to roll back rules that govern the financial industry, guns, the energy business and broadband internet providers.

articles.headline: ‘Turkish Trump,’ a Hotel Plan and a Tangle of Foreign Ties
articles.snippet: President Trump pledged that his business would avoid overseas deals during his tenure. But his company is pursuing a hotel project with a firm with deep foreign connections.
articles.abstract: President Trump pledged that his business would avoid overseas deals during his tenure. But his company is pursuing a hotel project with a firm with deep foreign connections.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Before taking office, Donald J. Trump pledged that his business empire would forgo new deals abroad while he was president. But as the Trump Organization unveils a new brand of hotels, that promise is not preventing the company from bringing foreign deals home.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Airbnb’s Rivals in China Hold Hands in a Nervous New Market
articles.snippet: The Silicon Valley firm introduces a new effort in a country where other foreign firms have stumbled — and where rivals offer door locks and advice to worried hosts.
articles.abstract: The Silicon Valley firm introduces a new effort in a country where other foreign firms have stumbled — and where rivals offer door locks and advice to worried hosts.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Sun Huifeng liked the idea of tapping Airbnb or one of its rising local competitors to rent out his spare Beijing bedroom.
articles.byline: By Amie Tsang and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Deadly Attack Near U.K. Parliament; Car Plows Victims on Westminster Bridge
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Theresa May, who was hastily evacuated from Parliament, called the assault a “sick and depraved terrorist attack.”
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Theresa May, who was hastily evacuated from Parliament, called the assault a “sick and depraved terrorist attack.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A knife-wielding assailant driving a sport utility vehicle mowed down panicked pedestrians and stabbed a police officer outside Parliament on Wednesday in a deadly assault, prompting the hasty evacuation of the prime minister and punctuating the threat of terrorism in Europe.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: China Bets on Sensitive U.S. Start-Ups, Worrying the Pentagon
articles.snippet: Beijing is pushing Chinese firms to invest in early-stage U.S. companies specializing in technology with potential military applications, a new report says.
articles.abstract: Beijing is pushing Chinese firms to invest in early-stage U.S. companies specializing in technology with potential military applications, a new report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the United States Air Force wanted help making military robots more perceptive, it turned to a Boston-based artificial intelligence start-up called Neurala. But when Neurala needed money, it got little response from the American military.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jane Perlez
